health_good_msg: Your connection looks healthy. All values are within normal range.
health_marginal_msg: Some values are outside the ideal range. This may not affect your internet experience yet, but is worth monitoring.
health_poor_msg: One or more values are critically out of range. You may experience connection issues such as slow speeds, dropouts, or high latency.
issue_ds_power_critical_desc: Signal level exceeds +/-10 dBmV. This usually indicates a cabling or amplifier problem. Contact your ISP if the issue persists.
issue_us_power_critical_desc: Transmit power exceeds 54 dBmV. Your modem is working too hard to reach the provider. Check cable connections or request a signal check from your ISP.
issue_us_power_warn_desc: Transmit power is between 50-54 dBmV (ideal: 35-49). May indicate signal loss on the line. Monitor this value over time.
issue_snr_critical_desc: SNR below 25 dB causes packet loss and connection instability. Common causes: damaged coax cable, loose connectors, or interference from splitters.
issue_snr_warn_desc: SNR between 25-30 dB (ideal: above 30 dB). Connection works but has reduced margin for error. Consider checking cable quality.
issue_uncorr_errors_high_desc: Over 10,000 uncorrectable errors detected. These cannot be recovered and cause data loss. If this number grows rapidly, contact your ISP.
no_data: No data available for this period.

bqm_setup_intro: BQM by ThinkBroadband monitors your connection quality by pinging your public IP from external servers. DOCSight can display BQM graphs alongside your modem data for a complete picture.
bqm_setup_benefit_1: Independent proof of connection issues (not just modem-side)
bqm_setup_benefit_2: Tracks latency, packet loss, and throughput 24/7
bqm_setup_benefit_3: Strengthens ISP complaints with third-party evidence
bqm_setup_step_1: Set up DynDNS on your router (e.g. MyFRITZ! on Fritz!Box) so BQM can find your IP
bqm_setup_step_2: Enable WAN ping/ICMP on your router so it responds to external pings (Fritz!Box: Internet â†’ Permit Access â†’ tick "Respond to ping")
bqm_setup_step_3: Go to thinkbroadband.com/broadband/monitoring, create a free account, and register your DynDNS address
bqm_setup_step_4: Once monitoring is active, copy your Share URL (ends in .png) and paste it in DOCSight Settings â†’ BQM Share URL

speedtest_setup_intro: Speedtest Tracker is a self-hosted app that runs periodic Ookla speed tests. DOCSight can display your speed test results alongside modem signal data for a complete picture of your connection.
speedtest_setup_benefit_1: Track actual download/upload speeds over time
speedtest_setup_benefit_2: Correlate speed drops with DOCSIS signal issues
speedtest_setup_benefit_3: Independent proof of speed issues for ISP complaints
speedtest_setup_step_2: In Speedtest Tracker, go to Settings → API and create an API token
speedtest_setup_step_3: Paste your Speedtest Tracker URL and API token in DOCSight Settings

explain_ds_power: Downstream power shows how strong the signal from your ISP reaches your modem. Values should be close to 0 dBmV. High or low values indicate cable or amplifier problems.
explain_us_power: Upstream power shows how hard your modem works to send data back. High values (>50 dBmV) mean the signal has to travel too far or passes through damaged cable.
explain_snr: Signal-to-Noise Ratio measures signal clarity. Think of it like trying to hear someone in a noisy room â€” the higher the SNR, the clearer the signal. Below 30 dB means noise is interfering.
explain_correctable: Correctable errors are data transmission errors that the modem could fix automatically. Some are normal, but rapid growth indicates cable quality issues.
explain_uncorrectable: Uncorrectable errors are data packets too damaged to repair. These cause actual data loss â€” slow loading, video buffering, or dropped connections.
explain_modulation: Modulation (like 256QAM) defines how much data fits in each signal pulse. Higher values = faster speed. If modulation drops (e.g. 256QAM â†’ 16QAM), it means the line quality degraded.
explain_ingress: The ingress score measures interference entering your cable from outside sources. Low scores indicate return path interference that can cause upload issues.
explain_gaming_index: The gaming index rates your connection for real-time applications. It considers latency (response time), jitter (consistency), and packet loss. Grade A = excellent, F = poor.
explain_ofdma: OFDMA is a DOCSIS 3.1 technology using wider frequency blocks for higher throughput. If available, your modem supports the latest standard.
explain_channel_count: The number of active channels affects your maximum speed. More channels = more bandwidth. If channels drop suddenly, it may indicate a hardware or signal problem.
